speaker: James
text: [dry] Eighty years of relative peace in Europe. An anomaly. We’ve collectively mistaken the exception for the rule.

speaker: Elena
text: An anomaly? War isn't 'normal,' James. It's a catastrophic failure.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] Historically, across 400 years, major European wars occurred every 30-40 years. We've lived inside a statistical improbability.

speaker: Elena
text: So this EUR 800 billion rearmament plan is just... Europe returning to its violent form?

speaker: James
text: The article's clear: it's the sixth great rearmament cycle. The pattern is absolutely unmistakable.

speaker: Elena
text: But the context is different. We have NATO, the EU. Institutions designed to prevent those old rivalries.

speaker: James
text: Did they prevent the 'peace dividend' from gutting Europe's military capacity? The Netherlands sold its entire tank fleet, remember?

speaker: Elena
text: A temporary correction, then. Post-Cold War euphoria, understandable, if naive.

speaker: James
text: Naive euphoria that left Europe unable to supply Ukraine with a million shells. Russia produces 3 million a year.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, that's a damning statistic. I'll give you that.

speaker: James
text: It gets worse. During World War II, the US went from 800 aircraft to 96,000 in five years. Europe can't make enough basic ammo today.

speaker: Elena
text: The industrial base was deliberately dismantled, James. That's the key. Not a lack of will, a lack of means.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. And now, the scramble. Poland spending 4% of GDP, the Baltics up to 6%.

speaker: Elena
text: While Spain caps it at 2.1%. That geographical divide is so frustrating.

speaker: James
text: It highlights the fault lines. Uneven threat perception. Divisions within the alliance.

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] And the fragmentation! Twenty-seven armies, twenty different tank types. It's ludicrous.

speaker: James
text: It means Europe gets far less military capability per euro. Seventy-eight percent of procurement from outside Europe, mostly America.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... that's actually devastating. 'Strategic autonomy,' my foot.

speaker: James
text: We discussed how complacency like this underpins 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West'.

speaker: Elena
text: So, what's the solution? More wasted money on protecting domestic defence industries?

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] Here's the twist the article raises. What if this rearmament actually forces integration?

speaker: Elena
text: How? Joint procurement programmes have a dismal track record. Eurofighter, A400M—nightmares.

speaker: James
text: But the scale is different now. Five percent of GDP. You simply cannot afford that waste anymore. Economic pressure will force consolidation.

speaker: Elena
text: You mean like the US after the Civil War? A truly national military becoming an integrating force? I don't want to agree with you on this, because it feels counter-intuitive to see military spending as a path to unity, but the numbers, and the sheer inefficiency, don't leave much room for any other logical conclusion if they genuinely want an effective defence.

speaker: James
text: The EU was born from sharing steel. Sharing an army could be the next logical step in that same pattern of integration.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, I see the argument for genuinely breaking the historical pattern there. It’s a compelling vision.

speaker: James
text: But the article also warns: Eisenhower's military-industrial complex. Defence budgets go up, rarely come down. The ratchet effect.

speaker: Elena
text: A valid concern. And the pressure on welfare states will be immense. Especially with countries like France and Italy already at eye-watering debt-to-GDP ratios.

speaker: James
text: And the threat goes next. These weapons are for Russia. But what about 'The North African Threat And Mediterranean Reunification'?

speaker: Elena
text: Climate change, population pressure... the Mediterranean frontier. The article suggests weapons built for one threat get used for another.

speaker: James
text: It’s not speculation, it’s the pattern. Britain rearmed against Germany, then fought the Cold War. America armed for the Soviets, then Vietnam.

speaker: Elena
text: So it's either integrated, stable Europe, or a fragmented one that just reruns the historical cycle with new, unexpected antagonists.

speaker: James
text: The bill for our 80-year anomaly has arrived. The question is, can we finally turn the machinery of war into the architecture of peace?
